creator.name: Notarisambt op St. Eustatius
creator.his_func: There was no notary public as a separate function on St Eustatius. Certain deeds (mortgage deeds; deeds of conveyance of real estate, ships and slaves; manumission deeds; muster rolls; passports; sworn statements) had to be passed before the Governor. These were termed secretarial deeds. The government secretary and the first sworn clerk (later called second secretary) were authorized to draw up notarial deeds like last wills, donations, probate inventories, and procurations. In 1834 an attorney was installed, who acted as Public Prosecutor and as notary public.
